Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[{"dependent_type":{"label":null,"value":null},"ai_cl_id":{"value":"ENVS2030","cl_id":"febefc23dbe1bc50be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"},"association_type":{"label":"Equivalents","value":"9"},"association_desc":"","associated_ai_cl_id":{"value":"GEOS2641","cl_id":"48e485a3db65bc50be4672f5f39619e3","key":"code"},"cl_id":"0bbefc23dbe1bc50be4672f5f3961942","assoc_credit_points":"6","assoc_active":"true","assoc_title":"Urban Environments","assoc_cl_id":"48e485a3db65bc50be4672f5f39619e3","assoc_short_title":"GEOS2641 - Urban Environments","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2022/GEOS2641","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"GEOS2641","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENVS2030 - Australian Cultural and Social Environments","description":"

This course provides an overview of human geography approaches to understanding urban environments in Australia and beyond. Contextualising cities as part of wider environmental understandings and concerns, this course considers the changes to thinking about urbanism over time. Case studies engage the varied and multiple experiences of urbanism, by for instance, class, ethnicity, gender, sexuality and so on, but also in times of increasing natural hazards and environmental awareness. Contemporary perspectives include (post)colonialism, critical race theory, environmentalism and consumerism, and new approaches to nature. Students will experience data generation using various quantitative and qualitative methodologies.

contentlets.description: This course provides an overview of human geography approaches to understanding urban environments in Australia and beyond. Contextualising cities as part of wider environmental understandings and concerns, this course considers the changes to thinking about urbanism over time. Case studies engage the varied and multiple experiences of urbanism, by for instance, class, ethnicity, gender, sexuality and so on, but also in times of increasing natural hazards and environmental awareness. Contemporary perspectives include (post)colonialism, critical race theory, environmentalism and consumerism, and new approaches to nature. Students will experience data generation using various quantitative and qualitative methodologies.
contentlets.title: Australian Cultural and Social Environments
